message: عن المستقبل (القريب؟) اللي الروبوتس هتقعدنا فيه في البيت، كلنا بدون استثناء :D
story: Ahmed Al-Amir shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Humans Need Not Apply
caption: youtube.com
description: Discuss this video: http://www.reddit.com/r/CGPGrey/comments/2dfh5v/humans_need_not_apply/ http://www.CGPGrey.com/ https://twitter.com/cgpgrey ## Robots, Etc...

data.message:
فكرة إننا نقعد في البيت لأن في روبوتات هتحل مكاننا ممكن تحصل لغاية حد معين ، بعد كده الانتاج بتاع الروبوتات ده هيفقد معناه لأن أغلب البشر هيبقوا عاطلين و معندهمش رفاهية شراء منتجات تتجاوز الأكل و الشرب والثورة هتتركز في أيدي قلة قليلة من البشر ، وده ربما يؤدي لانهيار النظام الاقتصادي و نشوء نظام تاني.

مجرد فكرة شاردة
الفيديو بيفند النقطة دي من ضمن نقاط تانية.
يا جدعان اتفرجوا ع الفيديو الأول، النقطة دي متفندة برضه :D
My Audio Driver crashed an I am too lazy to restart :( ,  too much open tabs and windows to just restart, Does it have subtitles? :D
I do not think so. You can always check the reddit discussion about it, though.

It's still a very long time before the idea of robots being able to do everything would be practical. Probably not even in our life time.

For example, for a self-driving car to replace regular cars, the most practical solution of this time is for all cars to be self-driving so they could be all connected to a backend that can synchronize their movements otherwise, they would be always used in limited locations (i.e. can they be used in Egypt or India? or what if while it's driving it went into a scenario that it was never programmed for?)

The idea of linking all self driving cars to a single backend is so limiting. Google self driving car has already driven 200K+ miles with only two minor accidents. All that is needed is a systematic environment.

This of course kills the possibility of using such solutions in a chaotic environment like Egypt or India. But, chaotic environments are beyond the scope of such technologies anyhow; people living there are completely safe from this high-end threat, since they are still succumbing to low-end ones.
Google self driving car needs many years to be even drivable for general public in US alone :)
As for a point like "a situation they were never programmed for", this is exactly what machine learning is about. As far as I am concerned, it has been growing rapidly in recent years.
I am not a fan of such general statements. Can you link this statement to numbers/estimations?
Machine learning is my daily job. Believe me, it's not that simple and it's still FAR from that said in the video :)

As for numbers/estimations, each of the prototype Google had carries $250,000-$300,000 worth of equipment + the base car price. For this to reach consumers, the price needs to go way down. which with the current technology, is far from practical (that also ignoring the fact that google tests are still not wide enough to work in all conditions, i.e. when it's snowy and there are accidents and several self-driving cars which went out of their lanes)

Well, I do not want to indulge too much in the *when* this will happen argument since it was not the point of the video, but rather how this will happen and how to manage it then. Plus, in a purely pragmatic sense, I am thinking one should try to be the producer rather than the consumer when it happens.
Well, you shouldn't even worry about that because for that level of robotic intelligence to happen, this is most probably outside our life time anyway
I am sure the exact same thing was said about every piece of technology that threatened human labor forces.
Well, it's difference this time because I work with one of the most advanced research labs that moves this entire industry for the whole planet and I would sure know if they were any close to that :)
What's the research lab's name?
Well, for personal reasons I would like to keep that for myself now :)

Ah, interesting. I'm curious though, you seem to do a lot in your day job. You published a post here once about data mining, mentioned it's your field of work as well. 

Now it's AI, it sounds like an interesting research lab, pulling the strings in the entire AI industry, I don't suppose if it's MIT they'd mind you sharing.
At some point I would :)
is the ugly truth, specially the programmers must admit the fact of everything we create and make is a tool to reduce the cost and need of human resources for better efficiency

We can make things that are better than us at labor or computation or even make something with better social intelligence, but we can't create something that is better than us in creation!
I don't think we will ever be able to create something that is more creative than us, because that means that this creation will be able to create things that are even more creative than it. Basically we're talking about software/robots ruling the world and enslaving us :D (if it's truly smarter than us, that it would trick us into doing things!)

So what I want to say is, when software/robots replace humans, all jobs will have something to do with creating and/or maintaining the software/robots this field will be very big with a lot of specialties and there will be companies competing, so there will still be a lot jobs, they would just be of a completely different kind :)
